item.title: Monthly Lung Disease Deaths in the UK
item.description:
Hello! In this post, I will be working with a data set from the UKLungDeaths data set that is built-in with R. The data set I am using is ldeaths which is a time-series that contains the number of monthly deaths from bronchitis, emphysema, and asthma of both men and women in the UK between the years of 1974-1979.

ldeaths contains the number of deaths in the UK over 72 months.

##       Jan  Feb  Mar  Apr  May  Jun  Jul  Aug  Sep  Oct  Nov  Dec
## 1974 3035 2552 2704 2554 2014 1655 1721 1524 1596 2074 2199 2512
## 1975 2933 2889 2938 2497 1870 1726 1607 1545 1396 1787 2076 2837
## 1976 2787 3891 3179 2011 1636 1580 1489 1300 1356 1653 2013 2823
## 1977 3102 2294 2385 2444 1748 1554 1498 1361 1346 1564 1640 2293
## 1978 2815 3137 2679 1969 1870 1633 1529 1366 1357 1570 1535 2491
## 1979 3084 2605 2573 2143 1693 1504 1461 1354 1333 1492 1781 1915

First, I will be loading the tidyverse package to analyze the data.

library(tidyverse)
## -- Attaching packages --------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.3.1 --
## v ggplot2 3.3.5     v purrr   0.3.4
## v tibble  3.1.6     v dplyr   1.0.7
## v tidyr   1.1.3     v stringr 1.4.0
## v readr   2.1.1     v forcats 0.5.1
## -- Conflicts ------------------------------------------ tidyverse_conflicts() --
## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
## x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

Next, I will be plotting the time-series, which displays the number of deaths due to lung disease over time in the UK.

From the graph, you can see that there is a peak in 1976 of the highest number of deaths due to lung disease. The highest number of deaths in this data set is:

max(ldeaths)
## [1] 3891

Not only did 1976 have the highest number of deaths, it also had the lowest number of deaths due to lung disease. The lowest number of deaths in this data set is:

min(ldeaths)
## [1] 1300

Now, I am calculating the total number of deaths due to lung disease in the UK between the years of 1974-1980. The total number of deaths is:

sum(ldeaths)
## [1] 148077

Next, I am converting the ldeaths time-series into a data frame, so I can group the data by month.

df.ldeaths <- data.frame(ldeaths, year = trunc(time(ldeaths)), 
month = month.abb[cycle(ldeaths)])

Here I am grouping the data by month and finding the total number of deaths in each month across all years. Then, I am graphing the monthly total number of deaths due to lung disease.

monthly_deaths <- df.ldeaths %>%
  mutate(month = fct_relevel(month, month.abb)) %>%
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(total = sum(ldeaths))
ggplot(monthly_deaths, aes(x=month, y= total, group = 1)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "Total Number of Deaths due to Lung Disease by Month",
       x = "Month",
       y = "Total Number of Deaths")

According to this graph, the total number of deaths due to lung disease is highest in January and decreases from January - September, then begins to increase between September - December. This is inline to the trend that is observed in the first graph where you see a decline following a peak, then an incline toward the end of each year.

Very interesting stuff!

item.title: The Effect of Vitamin C on Tooth Growth in Guinea Pigs
item.description:
Hi! In this post, I will be working with a data set from the ToothGrowth data set that is built-in with R. The data set is comes from an experiment in which 60 guinea pigsâ€™s length of odontoblasts were measured. Each animal received one of three dose levels of vitamin C (0.5, 1, and 2 mg/day) by either orange juice or ascorbic acid.

ToothGrowth is a data frame consisting of 60 observations and 3 variables.

  • len Tooth length
  • supp factor Supplement type (VC or OJ)
  • dose Dose in milligrams/day
data(ToothGrowth)
ToothGrowth
##     len supp dose
## 1   4.2   VC  0.5
## 2  11.5   VC  0.5
## 3   7.3   VC  0.5
## 4   5.8   VC  0.5
## 5   6.4   VC  0.5
## 6  10.0   VC  0.5
## 7  11.2   VC  0.5
## 8  11.2   VC  0.5
## 9   5.2   VC  0.5
## 10  7.0   VC  0.5
## 11 16.5   VC  1.0
## 12 16.5   VC  1.0
## 13 15.2   VC  1.0
## 14 17.3   VC  1.0
## 15 22.5   VC  1.0
## 16 17.3   VC  1.0
## 17 13.6   VC  1.0
## 18 14.5   VC  1.0
## 19 18.8   VC  1.0
## 20 15.5   VC  1.0
## 21 23.6   VC  2.0
## 22 18.5   VC  2.0
## 23 33.9   VC  2.0
## 24 25.5   VC  2.0
## 25 26.4   VC  2.0
## 26 32.5   VC  2.0
## 27 26.7   VC  2.0
## 28 21.5   VC  2.0
## 29 23.3   VC  2.0
## 30 29.5   VC  2.0
## 31 15.2   OJ  0.5
## 32 21.5   OJ  0.5
## 33 17.6   OJ  0.5
## 34  9.7   OJ  0.5
## 35 14.5   OJ  0.5
## 36 10.0   OJ  0.5
## 37  8.2   OJ  0.5
## 38  9.4   OJ  0.5
## 39 16.5   OJ  0.5
## 40  9.7   OJ  0.5
## 41 19.7   OJ  1.0
## 42 23.3   OJ  1.0
## 43 23.6   OJ  1.0
## 44 26.4   OJ  1.0
## 45 20.0   OJ  1.0
## 46 25.2   OJ  1.0
## 47 25.8   OJ  1.0
## 48 21.2   OJ  1.0
## 49 14.5   OJ  1.0
## 50 27.3   OJ  1.0
## 51 25.5   OJ  2.0
## 52 26.4   OJ  2.0
## 53 22.4   OJ  2.0
## 54 24.5   OJ  2.0
## 55 24.8   OJ  2.0
## 56 30.9   OJ  2.0
## 57 26.4   OJ  2.0
## 58 27.3   OJ  2.0
## 59 29.4   OJ  2.0
## 60 23.0   OJ  2.0

First, I am loading the tidyverse package to analyze the data.

library(tidyverse)
## -- Attaching packages --------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.3.1 --
## v ggplot2 3.3.5     v purrr   0.3.4
## v tibble  3.1.6     v dplyr   1.0.7
## v tidyr   1.1.3     v stringr 1.4.0
## v readr   2.1.1     v forcats 0.5.1
## -- Conflicts ------------------------------------------ tidyverse_conflicts() --
## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
## x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

Next, I am grouping the data by the supplement type used and finding the mean length of the measured odonotoblasts of each supplement type.

df.supp <- ToothGrowth %>%
  group_by(supp) %>%
  summarise(avg = mean(len))
df.supp
## # A tibble: 2 x 2
##   supp    avg
##   <fct> <dbl>
## 1 OJ     20.7
## 2 VC     17.0

According to this, guinea pigs that were given the orange juice supplements had on average longer odontoblasts.

Now, I am grouping the data by the dosage level given and finding the mean length of the measured odonotoblasts of each dosage level.

df.dose <- ToothGrowth %>%
  group_by(dose) %>%
  summarise(avg = mean(len))
df.dose
## # A tibble: 3 x 2
##    dose   avg
##   <dbl> <dbl>
## 1   0.5  10.6
## 2   1    19.7
## 3   2    26.1

Guinea pigs that were given 2.0 mg/day of vitamin C had the longest odontoblasts on average. This shows guinea pigs that were given higher dosage treatment had longer ondontoblasts.

Finally, I am grouping together the dosage and supplement type and finding the average length of the guinea pig odontoblasts by treatment of each supplement type and dosage level.

df.sd <- ToothGrowth %>%
  group_by(supp, dose) %>%
  summarise(avg = mean(len))
## `summarise()` has grouped output by 'supp'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.
df.sd
## # A tibble: 6 x 3
## # Groups:   supp [2]
##   supp   dose   avg
##   <fct> <dbl> <dbl>
## 1 OJ      0.5 13.2 
## 2 OJ      1   22.7 
## 3 OJ      2   26.1 
## 4 VC      0.5  7.98
## 5 VC      1   16.8 
## 6 VC      2   26.1

Guinea pigs that were given 2.0 mg/day of ascorbic acid had on average the longest measured odontoblasts (26.14). Therefore, according to this data, while attempting to maximize guinea pig odontoblast length, you should give them 2.0 mg/day of ascorbic acid.
